Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: T2K: From Tables to Knowledge

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Web has made humans smarter, providing ready access to vast amounts of knowledge and facts. The Semantic Web has the capacity to similarly enhance computer programs and devices by giving them access to enormous volumes of data, facts and knowledge. This project is exploring the feasibility of automatically extracting new knowledge directly from data found in spreadsheets, database relations, and document tables and representing it as highly interoperable linked open data (LOD) in the Semantic Web language RDF. The extraction is guided by probabilistic graphical models that use statistical information mined from current LOD knowledge resources. To demonstrate the potential payoff of the research, the system is used to extract knowledge from tables collected from medical journals and tables from web sites like data.gov.

While the W3C semantic web languages RDF and OWL are used to represent the knowledge, the results are applicable to other semantic data frameworks such as Microdata (Search Consortium), Freebase (Google), Probase (Microsoft) and the Open Graph (Facebook). The open sourced prototype software allows other researchers to experiment with automatically producing semantically enriched data from tables for their domains.

If successful, such software extraction systems are expected to become part of a new online knowledge ecology -- both consuming existing LOD knowledge to understand the intended meaning implicit in a table and producing new facts and knowledge that will become part of Web. This represents a dramatic increase in the breadth and depth of public semantic data that can make "big data" analytics more effective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tables are an integral part of documents, reports and Web pages, compactly encoding important information that can be difficult to express in text.  Table-like structures outside documents, such as spreadsheets, CSV files, log files and databases, are widely used to represent and share information. Tables are important to a number of domains including the Web, healthcare e-science and public policy. A Google study  found more than 150 million high quality relational tables on the Web.

Many governments share public data useful to citizens and businesses as tables. The U.S. government's data sharing website, for example, had nearly 400,000 such datasets as of September 2012. Medical researchers can assess treatment efficacy via a meta-analysis of previously published clinical trials, often using systems like MEDLINE to find relevant articles and extract key data, which is typically summarized in complex tables.  Our research created novel techniques to infer the semantics of a table (i.e. what are the elements that are represented in specific rows and columns, and the relationships across rows), and then export this information in formats such as Linked Open Data so that it can be made explicit and used by other (analytic) systems.  

This is an important problem becauase of lot of (scientific) data that informs important decisions, including in public policy, is published in tabular form in scientific literature. Our efforts have provided approaches and tools that can unlock this data and make it available to policy makers. In addition to developing general techniques, we've shown applications in two domains -- medical and cybersecurity. For the medical domain, we showed how metastudies could be partially automated, and data from tables in multiple papers brought into a common form for easy combination and analysis. Currently, this work is done by physicians who identify relevant papers and then combine data manually. In Cybersecurity, we showed how data in multiple system logs, which were of unknown structure. Previous work could only deal with situations where the log structure was known ahead of time.

This work has supported the efforts of the PIs, a graduate student who obtained his PhD and works for GE Research, and an MS student who works for a startup. The project has led to eleven publications in venues aprorpiate for this work, and the development of tools for information extraction from tables.

Modified by: Anupam Joshi
